column1: #This mapping was created following and expanding upon the SSSOM guidance: https://mapping-commons.github.io/sssom/spec/

column3: subject_definition
column12: object_definition
column26: comment
column27: syntax_comment

column3: The verbatim original spatial coordinates of the Location. The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.
column12: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system
column26: 'original spatial coordinates of the location' is semantically broader than 'latitude and longitude'. Note that the Coordinate Reference System 'epsg:4326' must be provided explicitly in dwc:verbatimSRS in order for the mapping to be complete.
column27: The DwC term expects a verbatim input (so anything really), whereas MIxS expects decimal degrees input as {float} {float}. Any verbatim terms in DwC are matched with relatedMatch to more prescribed terms in MIxS, as they can have free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax.

column3: The geographic latitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a Location. Positive values are north of the Equator, negative values are south of it. Legal values lie between -90 and 90, inclusive.
column12: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system
column26: DwC expects only the latitude (narrower), while MIxS expects both latitude and longitude (broader)
column27: The DwC term expects decimal degrees, and so does MIxS - however, the DwC term expects one value, while MIxS expects two

column3: The geographic longitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a Location. Positive values are east of the Greenwich Meridian, negative values are west of it. Legal values lie between -180 and 180, inclusive.
column12: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system
column26: DwC expects only the longitude (narrower), while MIxS expects both latitude and longitude (broader)
column27: The DwC term expects decimal degrees, and so does MIxS - however, the DwC term expects one value, while MIxS expects two

column3: The verbatim original latitude of the Location. The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.
column12: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system
column26: DwC expects only the latitude (narrower), while MIxS expects both latitude and longitude (broader)
column27: MIxS expects two input values in decimal degrees, while DwC only expects one as verbatim (so anything really). Any verbatim terms in DwC are matched with relatedMatch to more prescribed terms in MIxS, as they can have free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax.

column3: The verbatim original longitude of the Location. The coordinate ellipsoid, geodeticDatum, or full Spatial Reference System (SRS) for these coordinates should be stored in verbatimSRS and the coordinate system should be stored in verbatimCoordinateSystem.
column12: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system
column26: DwC expects only the longitude (narrower), while MIxS expects both latitude and longitude (broader)
column27: MIxS expects two input values in decimal degrees, while DwC only expects one as verbatim (so anything really). Any verbatim terms in DwC are matched with relatedMatch to more prescribed terms in MIxS, as they can have free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax.

column3: The original description of the depth below the local surface.
column12: Please refer to the definitions of depth in the environmental packages
column26: Both terms focus on a depth/vertical distance *below* some surface. Note that in Darwin Core, according to best practices, depth is measured in water from an air-water surface, while in other media the corresponding terms are dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters and dwc:maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters, where the values would be negative for depth. Thus, for a sediment at the bottom of a lake, there would be an elevation of the lake surface, the depth of the top of the sediment in the lake, and minimum and maximum distances below the sediment surface within which a sample was taken.
column27: The DwC term expects a verbatim input (so anything really), while MIxS expects a {float} {unit} entry in meters. Any verbatim terms in DwC are matched with relatedMatch to more prescribed terms in MIxS, as they can have free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax.

column2: Minimum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column3: The lesser distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
column12: Please refer to the definitions of depth in the environmental packages
column26: dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters is broader than MIxS:depth as it allows for both altitude and depth values (using positive and negative values, respectively), while the MIxS:depth definition only allows for depth ('below' the surface). Note that this competes with the MIxS:depth field allowing ranges or single points, while DwC expects only the upper depth/lower altitude limit (this could also be used to justify a broadMatch predicate). However, in this mapping we made the conscious decision to view the flipping between altitude and depth as more consequential. This is a matter of choice rather than an objective rationale. Note that in Darwin Core, according to best practices, depth is measured in water from an air-water surface, while in other media the corresponding terms are dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters and dwc:maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters, where the values would be negative for depth. Thus, for a sediment at the bottom of a lake, there would be an elevation of the lake surface, the depth of the top of the sediment in the lake, and minimum and maximum distances below the sediment surface within which a sample was taken.
column27: The example offered by DwC does not include the unit 'meter' as part of the entry in the field, whereas the MIxS syntax would expect the unit to be added. The numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

column2: Maximum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column3: The greater distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
column12: Please refer to the definitions of depth in the environmental packages
column26: dwc:maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters is broader than MIxS:depth as it allows for both altitude and depth values (using positive and negative values, respectively), while the MIxS:depth definition only allows for depth ('below' the surface). Note that this competes with the MIxS:depth field allowing ranges or single points, while DwC expects only the lower depth/upper altitude limit (this could also be used to justify a broadMatch predicate). However, in this mapping we made the conscious decision to view the flipping between altitude and depth as more consequential. This is a matter of choice rather than an objective rationale. Note that in Darwin Core, according to best practices, depth is measured in water from an air-water surface, while in other media the corresponding terms are dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters and dwc:maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters, where the values would be negative for depth. Thus, for a sediment at the bottom of a lake, there would be an elevation of the lake surface, the depth of the top of the sediment in the lake, and minimum and maximum distances below the sediment surface within which a sample was taken.
column27: The example offered by DwC does not include the unit 'meter' as part of the entry in the field, whereas the MIxS syntax would expect the unit to be added. The numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

column3: The lesser depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in meters.
column12: Please refer to the definitions of depth in the environmental packages
column26: The DwC term specifically addresses a range of depths, for which this term gives the minimum depth, whereas the MIxS term does not specify that it is about a depth range (expecting either a single depth measurement or a range)
column27: DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

column3: The greater depth of a range of depth below the local surface, in meters.
column12: Please refer to the definitions of depth in the environmental packages
column26: The DwC term specifically addresses a range of depths, for which this term gives the maximum depth, whereas the MIxS term does not specify that it is about a depth range (expecting either a single depth measurement or a range)
column27: DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

column2: Minimum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column3: The lesser distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
column12: Altitude is a term used to identify heights of objects such as airplanes, space shuttles, rockets, atmospheric balloons and heights of places such as atmospheric layers and clouds. It is used to measure the height of an object which is above the earth‚Äö√Ñ√¥s surface. In this context, the altitude measurement is the vertical distance between the earth's surface above sea level and the sampled position in the air
column26: dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters is broader than MIxS:alt as it allows for both altitude and depth values (using positive and negative values, respectively), while the MIxS:alt definition only allows for altitude ('above' the earth's surface). Note that this competes with the MIxS:alt field allowing ranges or single points (clarified in https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/389), while DwC expects only the upper depth/lower altitude limit (this could also be used to justify a broadMatch predicate). However, in this mapping we made the conscious decision to view the flipping between altitude and depth as more consequential. This is a matter of choice rather than an objective rationale. Note that in DwC, a range of altitude can be captured in the combination of the terms dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters and dwc:maximumDistanceAbveSurfaceInMeters. If a single value is given, the same value should be used in both DwC terms.
column27: DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields. However, this mapping is only based on the definition and term label (DwC example is not consistent).

column2: Maximum Distance Above Surface in Meters
column3: The greater distance in a range of distance from a reference surface in the vertical direction, in meters. Use positive values for locations above the surface, negative values for locations below. If depth measures are given, the reference surface is the location given by the depth, otherwise the reference surface is the location given by the elevation.
column12: Altitude is a term used to identify heights of objects such as airplanes, space shuttles, rockets, atmospheric balloons and heights of places such as atmospheric layers and clouds. It is used to measure the height of an object which is above the earth‚Äö√Ñ√¥s surface. In this context, the altitude measurement is the vertical distance between the earth's surface above sea level and the sampled position in the air
column26: dwc:maximumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters is broader than MIxS:alt as it allows for both altitude and depth values (using positive and negative values, respectively), while the MIxS:alt definition only allows for altitude ('above' the earth's surface). Note that this competes with the MIxS:alt field allowing ranges or single points (clarified in https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/389), while DwC expects only the upper depth/lower altitude limit (this could also be used to justify a broadMatch predicate). However, in this mapping we made the conscious decision to view the flipping between altitude and depth as more consequential. This is a matter of choice rather than an objective rationale. Note that in DwC, a range of altitude can be captured in the combination of the terms dwc:minimumDistanceAboveSurfaceInMeters and dwc:maximumDistanceAbveSurfaceInMeters. If a single value is given, the same value should be used in both DwC terms.
column27: DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields. However, this mapping is only based on the definition and term label (DwC example is not consistent).

column3: The original description of the elevation (altitude, usually above sea level) of the Location.
column12: Elevation of the sampling site is its height above a fixed reference point, most commonly the mean sea level. Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit
column26: Note that the MIxS term definition loosely distinguishes between elevation and altitude (Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit.), while the DwC term definition essentially equates them.
column27: The DwC term expects verbatim input (so anything really), whereas MIxS expects {float} {unit} in meter. Any verbatim terms in DwC are matched with relatedMatch to more prescribed terms in MIxS, as they can have free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax.

column3: The lower limit of the range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in meters.
column12: Elevation of the sampling site is its height above a fixed reference point, most commonly the mean sea level. Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit
column26: DwC expects only the lower elevation limit in meter (narrower), while MIxS expects a single elevation measurement at which the sample was taken.
column27: DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

column3: The upper limit of the range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in meters.
column12: Elevation of the sampling site is its height above a fixed reference point, most commonly the mean sea level. Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit
column26: DwC expects only the upper elevation limit in meter (narrower), while MIxS expects a single elevation measurement at which the sample was taken.
column27: DwC expects only the value {float}, whereas the MIxS syntax expects the value and the unit to be added {float} {unit}. Thus, the numeric/float values in the DwC fields are subsumed in / contained in the more complex alphanumeric string values (which includes the units) in the MIxS fields.

column3: The name of the country or major administrative unit in which the Location occurs.
column12: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (v 1.512) (http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ)
column26: the MIxS term includes both seas and countries, while DwC only refers to the country
column27: The DwC example only expects one country name, while MIxS expects two identifications of location (country or sea name + specific region name). Additionally MIxS expects terms from an ontology where appropriate, for which the input would be a termLabel[termID] combination. Despite these differences, one could interchangeably use these fields to hunt for the syntactic signature of country names (i.e. words delimited by a special character or whitespace) with a tagging or NLP routine, thus suggesting this to be a closeMatch. This closeness is only on country names (thus limited to the DwC -> MIxS direction of the mapping).

column3: The name of the water body in which the Location occurs.
column12: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (v 1.512) (http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ)
column26: the MIxS term includes both seas and countries, while DwC only refers to the sea.
column27: The DwC example only expects one sea identifier, while MIxS expects an additional region identifier (country or sea name + specific region name). Additionally, MIxS expects terms from an ontology where appropriate, for which the input would be a termLabel[termID] combination. Despite these differences, one could interchangeably use these fields to hunt for the syntactic signature of sea names (i.e. words delimited by a special character or whitespace) with a tagging or NLP routine, thus suggesting this to be a closeMatch. This closeness is only on sea names (thus limited to the DwC -> MIxS direction of the mapping).

column3: A list (concatenated and separated) of geographic names less specific than the information captured in the locality term.
column12: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (v 1.512) (http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ)
column26: DwC term encompasses any combination of geographic region names, while the MIxS term may either be the name of a country or a sea, followed by additional region information
column27: Both are string lists with some special characters that need not overlap. As noted [in this rubric](https://github.com/tdwg/gbwg/pull/78/files#r846255765), this qualifies the terms as relatedMatch.  DwC expects a list (of undefined length) of values separated by a vertical bar space  '|', while MIxS expects two words (country or sea name + specific region name). Additionally MIxS expects terms from an ontology where appropriate, for which the input would not only be a word but a termLabel[termID] combination.

column3: The date-time or interval during which an Event occurred. For occurrences, this is the date-time when the event was recorded. Not suitable for a time in a geological context.
column12: The time of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008; Except: 2008-01; 2008 all are ISO8601 compliant
column26: Events are semantically broader than sampling events (e.g. they could include observations too)
column27: DwC requests compliance with ISO 8601-1:2019, so does MIxS. Note, however, that this is only a recommendation in both cases. Thus, non ISO entries may be allowed. Stricter recommendations from both standards bodies would support this mapping.

column3: An identifier for the MaterialSample (as opposed to a particular digital record of the material sample). In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make the materialSampleID globally unique.
column12: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).
column27: Both expect PIDs of a sort (undefined and unrestricted as to what kind - a mix of letters, numbers, etc.). The mapping as exactMatch is further supported by the MIxS key referencing the DwC key.

column3: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers of other Organisms and their associations to this Organism.
column12: Description of relationship(s) between the subject organism and other organism(s) it is associated with. E.g., parasite on species X; mutualist with species Y. The target organism is the subject of the relationship, and the other organism(s) is the object
column26: The range of the MIxS examples is [free living|parasitism|commensalism|symbiotic|mutualism]. While the expectation created by the MIxS definition [parasite on species X; mutualist with species Y] would exactly match the DwC term, the examples given by MIxS do not. We‚Äôve opened an issue requesting this mismatch to be fixed on the GSC/MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/168. Focusing on the MIxS value syntax, it seems that the MIxS term is broader than the DwC term, as the latter will be more precise in any arbitrary case. E.g. Some worm is a parasite of a clam: DwC would capture parasite of clam, while MIxS would capture parasite of. One could also capture relationships with more metadata about the assertion using the ResourceRelationship extension to Darwin Core.
column27: Both fields accept numbers, letters, and special characters. DwC expects a list of terms and corresponding identifiers, linked with colons and both in quotation marks (quoted strings). The MIxS term expects a string (which could also include special characters and numbers - ref candidate phyla names).

column3: The name of, reference to, or description of the method or protocol used during an Event.
column12: The method or device employed for collecting the sample
column26: dwc:samplingProtocol covers both of the concepts samp_collect_device and samp_collect_process. , however,   the MIxS samp_collect_device field can accept either a reference to a protocol or a device, making it broader than the DwC field that only accepts protocol references. Based on the examples these could also be skos:exactMatch, but we are focusing on the definition for the semantic mapping. Please also note that the information that the dwc term and the samp_mat_process capture is often captured in the method steps in the EML (metadata about the dataset, not indexed in GBIF‚Äôs case), and less in the DwC terms themselves. This influences how people will use the terms in reality.
column27: DwC expects the name of, reference to, or description (which could also include a URI, IRI, etc.), while MIxS expects free text (or any other string-based value) as syntax. The DwC description may actively call for higher diversity of strings, the MIxS term is too loosely defined to narrow down the expected diversity of stings either. Following the same logic as with the dwC:verbatim fields, we are using relatedMatch to map the two terms to one another.

column3: The name of, reference to, or description of the method or protocol used during an Event.
column12: Any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment. This field accepts OBI, for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI
column26: dwc:samplingProtocol covers both of the concepts samp_collect_device and samp_collect_process. The object is narrower as the scope of the references in the MIxS field is limited; ‚ÄúThe name of, reference to, or description of the method [...]‚Äù vs a specific ontology term. The information that this term and samp_collect_device capture is often captured in the method steps in the EML (metadata about the dataset, not indexed in GBIF‚Äôs case), and less in the DwC terms themselves. This influences how people will use the terms in reality.
column27: DwC expects the name of, reference to, or description (which could also include a URI, IRI, etc.), while MIxS expects terms from an ontology where appropriate, for which the input would not only be a word but a termLabel[termID] combination

column3: A numeric value for a measurement of the size (time duration, length, area, or volume) of a sample in a sampling event.
column12: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected
column26: dwc:sampleSizeValue requires the units of the measure to be given in dwc:sampleSizeUnit.
column27: MIxS expects {float} {unit}, while DwC only expects {float}

column3: The unit of measurement of the size (time duration, length, area, or volume) of a sample in a sampling event.
column12: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected
column26: dwc:sampleSizeUnit  must accompany the measure given in dwc:sampleSizeValue.
column27: MIxS expects {float} {unit}, while DwC only expects {unit}

column3: A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise pointed to by the described resource.
column26: This mapping is a guess, given that the MIxS url term does not have a definition provided. Current conversation on the MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/67.
column27: The DwC field also accepts non-URL identifiers, while MIxS only accepts URLs.

column3: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, global unique identifier, URI) of media associated with the Occurrence.
column26: This mapping is a guess, given that the MIxS url term does not have a definition provided. Current conversation on the MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/67.
column27: The DwC field also accepts non-URL identifiers, while MIxS only accepts URLs.

column3: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers of other Occurrence records and their associations to this Occurrence.
column26: This mapping is a guess, given that the MIxS url term does not have a definition provided. Current conversation on the MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/67.
column27: The DwC field also accepts non-URL identifiers, while MIxS only accepts URLs.

column3: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers of other Organisms and their associations to this Organism.
column26: This mapping is a guess, given that the MIxS url term does not have a definition provided. Current conversation on the MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/67.
column27: The DwC term expects a link as well as text about the type of association, whereas MIxS only expects a URL.

column3: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with the Occurrence.
column26: This mapping is a guess, given that the MIxS url term does not have a definition provided. Current conversation on the MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/67.
column27: The DwC would expect a comma separated list of citations, URIs, etc., thus accepting non-URL identifiers, while MIxS only accepts URLs.

column3: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, global unique identifier, URI) of genetic sequence information associated with the Occurrence.
column26: This mapping is a guess, given that the MIxS url term does not have a definition provided. Current conversation on the MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/67.
column27: The DwC field also accepts non-URL identifiers, while MIxS only accepts URLs.

column3: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers or names of taxa and their associations with the Occurrence.
column26: This mapping is a guess, given that the MIxS url term does not have a definition provided. Current conversation on the MIxS issue tracker: https://github.com/GenomicsStandardsConsortium/mixs/issues/67. DwC expects only the identifiers (DOI to publication, global unique ID, URI) to associated taxa, while MIxS seems to expect a url to anything related
column27: The DwC term would expect a list of IDs (could be links) or names, while MIxS expects URLs only.
